did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: The Cheney-Downing Collection consists of business and personal papers of a father, George Locke Cheney (1857–1933), and his daughter, Harriet Cheney Downing (1895–1987). Harriet served as her father’s personal secretary and maintained family papers after her father's death. The collection contains correspondence relating to her father's business (Comstock, Cheney & Co.) until 1936 as well as personal correspondence relating to his charitable and family activities. Harriet's own correspondence is included and relates to family, charitable, financial, and household activities.
did.physloc: Manuscript Vault, Connecticut River Museum Chandlery building.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: George L. Cheney (1857–1933) was the son of George Arthur Cheney and Sarah Bucklin Greene Cheney. When G. L. Cheney was three years old his parents moved to Essex and his father became a partner (and later President) in the ivory manufacturing concern of Comstock, Cheney & Co. Comstock, Cheney was one of several Connecticut companies using ivory in the manufacture of novelty items (billiard balls, hair combs, toothpicks, game pieces, etc.) as well as piano keys. This competitive industry saw the eventual merging of several smaller local companies (George Read & Co., Pratt Brothers Company, Julius Pratt and Company) with Comstock, Cheney. In the 1930s, Comstock, Cheney merged with their competitor, Pratt, Read & Company.

George L. and Harriet Carnes Cheney had four daughters, the youngest named Harriet. Harriet Cheney (1895–1987) married Augustus C. Downing, a New York banker and lived in both New York and Essex during her lifetime.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The papers relating to George L. Cheney pertain to his business, family, and charitable interests dating from 1894-1936. Among the items in the collection are documents related to the family business. These concern the operation of a manufacturing enterprise, including: procurement of raw materials, product transportation, advertising, sales, weights, and investments. Non-business material includes requests for donations from many different charities.

Harriet Cheney Downey’s papers deal largely with family, financial and property concerns. She maintained the housekeeping accounts for her homes in New York and Essex as well as her family's charitable contributions. She also received regular income from shares in her family's company. After the death of her parents, Harriet and her sisters had the task of selling the New York City properties and there is much correspondence about that endeavor.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in 26 boxes by topic (e.g., Real estate) and then chronologically. The 16 volumes contain carbon copies of correspondence bound together and arranged chronologically. Each volume contains about two years of correspondence. For example, Volume 6 contains letters dated 1910 - 1912.
